charset.description: The Unicode Standard (UTF-8) covers (almost) all the characters, punctuations, and symbols in the world. Please use that.
charset.title: Declare a charset in your document

doctype.description: The <!DOCTYPE> declaration is not an HTML tag; it is an instruction to the web browser about what version of HTML the page is written in.
doctype.title: Declare a doctype in your document

language.description: According to the W3C recommendation you should declare the primary language for each Web page with the lang attribute inside the <html> tag https://www.w3.org/International/questions/qa-html-language-declarations#basics.
language.title: Declare the language code for your document

layoutShift.advice: You have elements that shift. You should manually check the filmstrip or video and check if it will affect the user.
layoutShift.description: Cumulative Layout Shift measures the sum total of all individual layout shift scores for every unexpected layout shift that occurs during the entire lifespan of the page. A layout shift occurs any time a visible element changes its position from one rendered frame to the next.
offending: SECTION channel channel--left channel--editors-picks fs-content csf-row et-rows row_5b3142a75c5ed

layoutShift.title: Cumulative Layout Shift

metaDescription.description: Use a page description to make the page more relevant to search engines.
metaDescription.title: Meta description

optimizely.description: Use Optimizely with care because it hurts your performance since JavaScript is loaded synchronously inside of the head tag, making the first paint happen later. Only turn on Optimzely (= load the javascript) when you run your A/B tests.
optimizely.title: Only use Optimizely when you need it

pageTitle.description: Use a title to make the page more relevant to search engines.
pageTitle.title: Page title

spdy.description: Chrome dropped supports for SPDY in Chrome 51, upgrade to HTTP/2 as soon as possible. The page has more users (browsers) supporting HTTP/2 than supports SPDY.
spdy.title: EOL for SPDY in Chrome

url.description: A clean URL is good for the user and for SEO. Make them human readable, avoid too long URLs, spaces in the URL, too many request parameters, and never ever have the session id in your URL.
url.title: Have a good URL format

longHeaders.title: Do not send too long headers
longHeaders.description: Do not send response headers that are too long.
longHeaders.advice: https://www.linkedin...in.com/px/li_sync has a header content-security-policy that is 1170 characters long. https://cdn.ampproje...00/amp4ads-v0.mjs has a header content-security-policy that is 647 characters long. https://cdn.ampproje...p-ad-exit-0.1.mjs has a header content-security-policy that is 647 characters long. https://cdn.ampproje...analytics-0.1.mjs has a header content-security-policy that is 647 characters long. https://cdn.ampproje...-fit-text-0.1.mjs has a header content-security-policy that is 647 characters long. https://cdn.ampproje.../amp-form-0.1.mjs has a header content-security-policy that is 647 characters long. https://stags.blueka...ai.com/site/52847 has a header set-cookie that is 692 characters long.

manyHeaders.title: Avoid use too many response headers
manyHeaders.description: Avoid send too many response headers.

thirdParty.title: Avoid use too many third party responses
thirdParty.description: Do not load most of your content from third party URLs.
thirdParty.advice: The page do more requests to third party domains (184 requests and 2.7 MB) then first party (1 requests and 83 B). The page transfer more bytes from third party domains (2.7 MB) then first party (83 B). The regex .*aliyuncs.* was used to calculate first/third party requests.

unnecessaryHeaders.title: Avoid Unnecessary Headers
unnecessaryHeaders.description: Do not send headers that you don't need. We look for p3p, cache-control and max-age, pragma, server and x-frame-options headers. Have a look at Andrew Betts - Headers for Hackers talk as a guide https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k92ZbrY815c or read https://www.fastly.com/blog/headers-we-dont-want.
unnecessaryHeaders.advice: There are 41 responses that sets a p3p header. There are 101 responses that sets both a max-age and expires header. There are 51 responses that sets a pragma no-cache header (that is a request header). There are 1 response that sets a x-frame-options:sameorigin header. There are 159 responses that sets a server header.

info.metaDescription: Forbes is a global media company, focusing on business, investing, technology, entrepreneurship, leadership, and lifestyle.

avoidScalingImages.description: It's easy to scale images in the browser and make sure they look good in different devices, however that is bad for performance! Scaling images in the browser takes extra CPU time and will hurt performance on mobile. And the user will download extra kilobytes (sometimes megabytes) of data that could be avoided. Don't do that, make sure you create multiple version of the same image server-side and serve the appropriate one.
avoidScalingImages.title: Don't scale images in the browser

cssPrint.description: Loading a specific stylesheet for printing slows down the page, even though it is not used. You can include the print styles inside your other CSS file(s) just by using an @media query targeting type print.
cssPrint.title: Do not load specific print stylesheets.

fastRender.description: The critical rendering path is what the browser needs to do to start rendering the page. Every file requested inside of the head element will postpone the rendering of the page, because the browser need to do the request. Avoid loading JavaScript synchronously inside of the head (you should not need JavaScript to render the page), request files from the same domain as the main document (to avoid DNS lookups) and inline CSS or use server push for really fast rendering and a short rendering path.
fastRender.title: Avoid slowing down the critical rendering path

googletagmanager.advice: The page is using Google Tag Manager, this is a performance risk since non-tech users can add JavaScript to your page.
googletagmanager.description: Google Tag Manager makes it possible for non tech users to add scripts to your page that will downgrade performance.
googletagmanager.title: Avoid using Google Tag Manager

inlineCss.advice: The page has both inline CSS and CSS requests even though it uses a HTTP/2-ish connection. If you have many users on slow connections, it can be better to only inline the CSS. Run your own tests and check the waterfall graph to see what happens.
inlineCss.description: In the early days of the Internet, inlining CSS was one of the ugliest things you can do. That has changed if you want your page to start rendering fast for your user. Always inline the critical CSS when you use HTTP/1 and HTTP/2 (avoid doing CSS requests that block rendering) and lazy load and cache the rest of the CSS. It is a little more complicated when using HTTP/2. Does your server support HTTP push? Then maybe that can help. Do you have a lot of users on a slow connection and are serving large chunks of HTML? Then it could be better to use the inline technique, becasue some servers always prioritize HTML content over CSS so the user needs to download the HTML first, before the CSS is downloaded.
inlineCss.title: Inline CSS for faster first render

jquery.description: There are sites out there that use multiple versions of jQuery on the same page. You shouldn't do that because the user will then unnecessarily download extra data. Cleanup the code and make sure you only use one version.
jquery.title: Avoid using more than one jQuery version per page

longTasks.advice: The page has 5 CPU long tasks with the total of 474 ms. However the CPU Long Task is depending on the computer/phones actual CPU speed, so you should measure this on the same type of the device that your user is using. Use Geckoprofiler for Firefox or Chromes tracelog to debug your Long Task.
longTasks.description: Long CPU tasks locks the thread. To the user this is commonly visible as a "locked up" page where the browser is unable to respond to user input; this is a major source of bad user experience on the web today. However the CPU Long Task is depending on the computer/phones actual CPU speed, so you should measure this on the same type of the device that your user is using.
longTasks.title: Avoid CPU Long Tasks

spof.advice: The page has 1 request inside of the head that can cause a SPOF (single point of failure). Load them asynchronously or move them outside of the document head.
spof.description: A page can be stopped from loading in the browser if a single JavaScript, CSS, and in some cases a font, couldn't be fetched or is loading really slowly (the white screen of death). That is a scenario you really want to avoid. Never load 3rd-party components synchronously inside of the head tag.
spof.title: Avoid Frontend single point of failures

thirdPartyAsyncJs.description: Use JavaScript snippets that load the JS files asynchronously in order to speed up the user experience and avoid blocking the initial load.
thirdPartyAsyncJs.title: Always load third-party JavaScript asynchronously

assetsRedirects.title: Avoid doing redirects
assetsRedirects.description: A redirect is one extra step for the user to download the asset. Avoid that if you want to be fast. Redirects are even more of a showstopper on mobile.
assetsRedirects.advice: The page has 16 redirects. 16 requests are from other domains, it could be 3rd-party assets doing unnecessary redirects. :(

cacheHeaders.title: Avoid extra requests by setting cache headers
cacheHeaders.description: The easiest way to make your page fast is to avoid doing requests to the server. Setting a cache header on your server response will tell the browser that it doesn't need to download the asset again during the configured cache time! Always try to set a cache time if the content doesn't change for every request.
cacheHeaders.advice: The page has 88 requests that are missing a cache time. Configure a cache time so the browser doesn't need to download them every time. It will save 690.4 kB the next access.

cacheHeadersLong.title: Long cache headers is good
cacheHeadersLong.description: Setting a cache header is good. Setting a long cache header (at least 30 days) is even better beacause then it will stay long in the browser cache. But what do you do if that asset change? Rename it and the browser will pick up the new version.
cacheHeadersLong.advice: The page has 56 requests that have a shorter cache time than 30 days (but still a cache time).

compressAssets.title: Always compress text content
compressAssets.description: In the early days of the Internet there were browsers that didn't support compressing (gzipping) text content. They do now. Make sure you compress HTML, JSON, JavaScript, CSS and SVG. It will save bytes for the user; making the page load faster and use less bandwith.
compressAssets.advice: The page has 1 request that are served uncompressed. You could save a lot of bytes by sending them compressed instead.

connectionKeepAlive.title: Don't close a connection that is used multiple times
connectionKeepAlive.description: Use keep-alive headers and don't close the connection when we have multiple requests to the same domain. There has been some hacks in the past that suggested closing the connection as fast as possible in order to create new ones, but that shouldn't be applicable anymore.

cpuTimeSpentInRendering.title: Avoid spend too much CPU time to render the page
cpuTimeSpentInRendering.description: You need to be able to render the page fast. This metric depends on which computer/device you run on but the limit here is high: Spending more time than 500 ms will alert this advice.

cpuTimeSpentInScripting.title: Avoid executing too much JavaScript
cpuTimeSpentInScripting.description: Do not run too much JavaSript, that will slow down the page for your user. This metric depends on which computer/device you run on but the limit here is high: Spending more time than 1000 ms will alert this advice

cssSize.title: Total CSS size shouldn't be too big
cssSize.description: Delivering a massive amount of CSS to the browser is not the best thing you can do, because it means more work for the browser when parsing the CSS against the HTML and that makes the rendering slower. Try to send only the CSS that is used on that page. And make sure to remove CSS rules when they aren't used anymore.

documentRedirect.title: Avoid redirecting the main document
documentRedirect.description: You should never ever redirect the main document, because it will make the page load slower for the user. Well, you should redirect the user if the user tries to use HTTP and there's an HTTPS version of the page. The coach checks for that. :)

favicon.title: The favicon should be small and cacheable
favicon.description: It is easy to make the favicon big but please avoid doing that, because every browser will then perform an unnecessarily large download. And make sure the cache headers are set for a long time for the favicon. It is easy to miss since it's another content type.

fewFonts.title: Avoid too many fonts
fewFonts.description: How many fonts do you need on a page for the user to get the message? Fonts can slow down the rendering of content, try to avoid loading too many of them because worst case it can make the text invisible until they are loaded (FOITflash of invisible text), best case they will flicker the text content when they arrive.
fewFonts.advice: The page has 6 font requests. Do you really need them? What value does the fonts give the user?

fewRequestsPerDomain.title: Avoid too many requests per domain [HTTP/1]
fewRequestsPerDomain.description: Browsers have a limit on how many concurrent requests they can do per domain when using HTTP/1. When you hit the limit, the browser will wait before it can download more assets on that domain. So avoid having too many requests per domain.
fewRequestsPerDomain.advice: There are almost no limits on HTTP/2 connections with the number of requests, but that is not completely true. It depends on how they are downloaded. Please check your HAR file, does it look OK?

headerSize.title: Response headers should't be too big [HTTP/1]
headerSize.description: Avoid a lot of cookies and other stuff that makes your headers big when you use HTTP/1 because the headers are not compressed. You will send extra data to the user.
headerSize.advice: The page uses an HTTP/2 connection and the headers are sent compressed, that's good. The current coach version cannot say if the size is good or not.

imageSize.title: Total image size shouldn't be too big
imageSize.description: Avoid having too many large images on the page. The images will not affect the first paint of the page, but it will eat bandwidth for the user.

javascriptSize.title: Total JavaScript size shouldn't be too big
javascriptSize.description: A lot of JavaScript often means you are downloading more than you need. How complex is the page and what can the user do on the page? Do you use multiple JavaScript frameworks?
javascriptSize.advice: The total JavaScript transfer size is 1.8 MB and the uncompressed size is 6.2 MB. This is totally crazy! There is really room for improvement here.

mimeTypes.title: Avoid using incorrect mime types
mimeTypes.description: It's not a great idea to let browsers guess content types (content sniffing), in some cases it can actually be a security risk.
mimeTypes.advice: The page has 8 misconfigured mime types.

optimalCssSize.title: Make each CSS response small
optimalCssSize.description: Make CSS responses small to fit into the magic number TCP window size of 14.5 KB. The browser can then download the CSS faster and that will make the page start rendering earlier.

pageSize.title: Total page size shouldn't be too big
pageSize.description: Avoid having pages that have a transfer size over the wire of more than 2 MB (desktop) and 1 MB (mobile) because that is really big and will hurt performance and will make the page expensive for the user if she/he pays for the bandwidth.
pageSize.advice: The page total transfer size is 2.7 MB, which is more than the coach limit of 2 MB. That is really big and you need to make it smaller.

privateAssets.title: Don't use private headers on static content
privateAssets.description: If you set private headers on content, that means that the content are specific for that user. Static content should be able to be cached and used by everyone. Avoid setting the cache header to private.
privateAssets.advice: The page has 29 requests with private headers. Make sure that the assets really should be private and only used by one user. Otherwise, make it cacheable for everyone.

responseOk.title: Avoid missing and error requests
responseOk.description: Your page should never request assets that return a 400 or 500 error. These requests are never cached. If that happens something is broken. Please fix it.
responseOk.advice: The page has 1 error response. The page has 1 response with code 404.

ampPrivacy.description: You share share private user information with Google that your user hasn't agreed on sharing.
ampPrivacy.title: Avoid including AMP

facebook.description: You share share private user information with Facebook that your user hasn't agreed on sharing.
facebook.title: Avoid including Facebook

fingerprint.description: Fingerprinting consists of collecting different kinds of information about the user with the goal of building a unique "fingerprint" for them. Different types of fingerprinting are used on the web by trackers. Browser fingerprinting use characteristics specific to the browser of the user, relying on the fact that the chance of another user having the exact same browser set-up is fairly small if there are a large enough number of variables to track
fingerprint.title: Do not fingerprint your user.

ga.advice: The page is using Google Analytics meaning you share your users private information with Google. You should use analytics that care about user privacy, something like https://matomo.org.
ga.description: Google Analytics share private user information with Google that your user hasn't agreed on sharing.
ga.title: Avoid using Google Analytics

https.description: A page should always use HTTPS (https://https.cio.gov/everything/). You also need that for HTTP/2. You can get your free SSL/TLC certificate from https://letsencrypt.org/.
https.title: Serve your content securely

surveillance.description: Do not use web sites that harvest private user information and sell it to other companies. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surveillance_capitalism
surveillance.title: Avoid using surveillance web sites

youtube.description: If you include Youtube videos on your page, you are sharing private user information with Google.
youtube.title: Avoid including Youtube videos

contentSecurityPolicyHeader.title: Use a good Content-Security-Policy header to make sure you you avoid Cross Site Scripting (XSS) attacks.
contentSecurityPolicyHeader.description: Content Security Policy is delivered via a HTTP response header, and defines approved sources of content that the browser may load. It can be an effective countermeasure to Cross Site Scripting (XSS) attacks and is also widely supported and usually easily deployed. https://scotthelme.co.uk/content-security-policy-an-introduction/.
contentSecurityPolicyHeader.advice: Set a Content-Security-Policy header to make sure you are not open for Cross Site Scripting (XSS) attacks. You can start with setting a Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only header, that will only report the violation, not stop the download.

disableFLoCHeader.title: Set a permission policy header that opt out your users being tracked in Chrome by FLoC.
disableFLoCHeader.description: Googles new tracking method is called Federated Learning of Cohorts (FLoC) and it groups you based on your interests and demographics, derived from your browsing history, to enable creepy advertising and other content targeting without third-party cookies. You can avoid that by setting a Permissions-Policy header with the value of interest-cohort=(). See https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2021/03/googles-floc-terrible-idea.
disableFLoCHeader.advice: Set a permission policy header that opt out Chrome for tracking what your users do on your site.

googleReCaptcha.title: Avoid using Google reCAPTCHA
googleReCaptcha.description: You should avoid using Google reCAPTCHA since it will share your users information with Google.

mixedContent.title: Serve all responses on HTTPS (when you are on HTTPS)
mixedContent.description: You need to make sure that if you are on HTTPS, all responses are on HTTPS so that the content served are secured.

referrerPolicyHeader.title: Set a referrer-policy header to make sure you do not leak user information.
referrerPolicyHeader.description: Referrer Policy is a new header that allows a site to control how much information the browser includes with navigations away from a document and should be set by all sites. https://scotthelme.co.uk/a-new-security-header-referrer-policy/.
referrerPolicyHeader.advice: Set a referrer-policy header to make sure you do not leak user information.

strictTransportSecurityHeader.title: Set a strict transport header to make sure the user always use HTTPS.
strictTransportSecurityHeader.description: The HTTP Strict-Transport-Security response header (often abbreviated as HSTS) lets a web site tell browsers that it should only be accessed using HTTPS, instead of using HTTP. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Strict-Transport-Security.

thirdPartyCookies.title: Avoid third party cookies that is used to track the user.
thirdPartyCookies.description: Third party cookies are used to track the user. They are automatically blocked in Safari and Firefox.
thirdPartyCookies.advice: The page sets 16 third party cookies.

thirdPartyPrivacy.title: Do not share user data with third parties.
thirdPartyPrivacy.description: Using third party requests shares user information with that third party. Please avoid that! The project https://github.com/patrickhulce/third-party-web is used to categorize first/third party requests.
thirdPartyPrivacy.advice: The page has 77% requests that are 3rd party (142 requests with a size of 1.8 MB). The page also have request to companies that harvest data from users and do not respect users privacy (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surveillance_capitalism).  The page do 19 analytics requests and uses 7 analytics tools. The page do 93 ad requests and uses 17 ad tools. The page do 50 survelliance requests and uses 8 survelliance tools. The page do 3 tag-manager requests and uses 2 tag-manager tools. The page do 4 social requests and uses 1 social tool. The page do 8 marketing requests and uses 1 marketing tool. The page do 7 utility requests and uses 2 utility tools. The page do 5 content requests and uses 1 content tool.
